instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

No green light. Light liquid damage. to pp3v42 area 



<RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> burnt.
Replaced these. 

<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN</SIGNAL> 2.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> 1.1v

pp3v42 = 0.008v

Replaced:
<CAPACITOR>C6992</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>
C69901
<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6996</RESISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C6995</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR>
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>  
<CHIP>U6900</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> diode mode to ground0.35v
pp3v42 diode mode to ground 0.305v

Got lost on this one now would appreciate any help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: 0.3 is fine so there is no short. <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> burned for a reason so check voltages at <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Thank you duke.


<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> 
pin1 0.68v
pin2 0v (no battery connected)
pin3 0.67v




<DIODE>D6990</DIODE>

pin1 0.007
pin2 0.007
pin3 0.003
pin4 0.004
pin5 0
pin6 0.635
pin7 0.044
pin8 0.635

The probe point next to <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR> looks bad so i ran a wire from <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> to <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6992</CAPACITOR> but this didn't change anything. continuity checked out.
possible that <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> leaking through the probe point ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: I assume you checked <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR>. So it seems <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> is not opening, voltages there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Thanks Duke,

Yes <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> was initially burnt and was replaced.


<TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>
pin 5/6 2.36v
pin 4 0.7v
pin 1/2/3 0.657v

replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> again in case donor board duff - no change.


<RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR> 99k
<RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR> 10.1k
<RESISTOR>R6912</RESISTOR> 68k
all measure within spec.

replaced <CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR>
<RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR> 
<RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>

no change

I concur that <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> is not opening but i don't know what else would cause it not to.

Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Again I ask for voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>
pin 5/6 2.36v
pin 4 0.7v
pin 1/2/3 0.657v

these were in the above post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Oops sorry didn't see that.
So the charger is shutting down/not turning on. Try with a Chinese charger or an external power supply hooked up to the magsafe connector. This will bypass the protection circuit in the original charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Chinese charger gets green light and machine boots. Still nothing with original 85w - worth pursuing or just supplying chinese charger ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: There is probably an issue around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> or <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>. Check all current sense resistors and traces to <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>.
